longDescription: Fatima is one of the most important Marian shrines in the world, where the Virgin Mary reportedly appeared to three shepherd children - Lucia dos Santos (10), Francisco Marto (9), and Jacinta Marto (7) - six times between May 13 and October 13, 1917. The apparitions occurred during World War I, and the Virgin's messages centered on prayer (especially the Rosary), penance, conversion, and the consecration of Russia to her Immaculate Heart. The final apparition concluded with the 'Miracle of the Sun,' witnessed by an estimated 70,000 people. The three 'Secrets of Fatima' revealed to the children concerned a vision of hell, devotion to Mary's Immaculate Heart and the fate of Russia, and a vision of persecution and the assassination attempt on a pope (interpreted as Pope John Paul II in 1981). The apparitions were approved by the local bishop in 1930, and Fatima has since become one of the most visited Catholic pilgrimage sites in the world, receiving approximately 6 million visitors annually.
shortDescription: Major Marian apparition site where the Virgin Mary appeared to three shepherd children in 1917, culminating in the 'Miracle of the Sun' witnessed by 70,000 people. The messages of Fatima call for prayer, penance, and devotion to Mary's Immaculate Heart.

name: Fatima
displayName: Sanctuary of Our Lady of Fatima
associatedEvents: Assassination attempt on Pope John Paul II (May 13, 1981)

luciaDosSantos.role: Primary visionary; the only one who heard the Virgin speak
luciaDosSantos.laterLife: Became a Carmelite nun (Sr. Maria Lucia of Jesus and the Immaculate Heart); wrote her memoirs recording the apparitions; met multiple popes

franciscoMarto.role: Could see but not hear the apparitions; devoted himself to 'consoling God' through prayer
franciscoMarto.death: Died of Spanish flu pandemic; canonized May 13, 2017

jacintaMarto.role: Could see and hear; particularly affected by vision of hell; offered sufferings for sinners
jacintaMarto.death: Died of Spanish flu; canonized May 13, 2017

relatedEvents: Three secrets revealed to the children
Papal visits (Paul VI, 1967; John Paul II, 1982, 1991, 2000; Benedict XVI, 2010; Francis, 2017)

firstSecret.content: Vision of hell shown to the children
firstSecret.description: The Virgin showed the children a terrifying vision of hell where sinners' souls fall 'like snowflakes.' This vision profoundly affected young Jacinta, who offered many sacrifices for the conversion of sinners.
firstSecret.theologicalContext: Consistent with Catholic teaching on the reality of hell and the consequences of unrepented mortal sin

secondSecret.content: Devotion to the Immaculate Heart and prophecies about Russia
secondSecret.description: Mary promised that World War I would end but warned that if people did not cease offending God, a worse war would begin during the pontificate of Pius XI. She requested the consecration of Russia to her Immaculate Heart and Communion of Reparation on First Saturdays.
prophecies: If offenses against God continued, a worse war would break out
Russia would spread her errors (interpreted as Communism)
The Holy Father would suffer much
Eventually the Immaculate Heart would triumph and Russia would be converted
secondSecret.fulfillment: World War II, spread of Soviet Communism, persecutions - interpreted as fulfillment; consecration of Russia debated

thirdSecret.content: Vision of the 'bishop dressed in white' and martyrdom
thirdSecret.description: Written down by Sister Lucia in 1944, kept sealed until 2000. Describes a vision of a pope ('bishop dressed in white') climbing a mountain, passing through a city in ruins, reaching the top to be killed along with other bishops, priests, and laity.
thirdSecret.vaticanInterpretation: Cardinal Ratzinger (later Pope Benedict XVI) interpreted this as referring to the 20th century's persecution of the Church, culminating symbolically in the 1981 assassination attempt on Pope John Paul II.
thirdSecret.disclosure: Revealed by the Vatican on May 13, 2000, with theological commentary by Cardinal Ratzinger

miracleOfTheSun.witnesses: Estimated 70,000 people, including skeptics and journalists
miracleOfTheSun.description: The sun appeared to 'dance,' spin, change colors, and plunge toward the earth before returning to normal. Witnesses reported that their rain-soaked clothes dried instantly.
miracleOfTheSun.journalisticAccounts: Secular newspaper O Seculo published a detailed account despite its anticlerical stance
miracleOfTheSun.theologicalInterpretation: Understood as miraculous sign confirming the authenticity of the apparitions
miracleOfTheSun.significance: One of the most witnessed alleged miracles in modern history

mariology.immaculateHeart: Fatima's central Marian theme is devotion to Mary's Immaculate Heart - her interior life of love, prayer, and suffering united with Christ. The consecration of individuals, families, and nations to the Immaculate Heart is a key practice.
mariology.rosary: The Virgin appeared with a rosary and repeatedly emphasized its power for peace and conversion. She identified herself as 'the Lady of the Rosary.'
mariology.coredemption: The emphasis on offering sufferings with Mary for sinners reflects the Catholic understanding of Mary's participation in Christ's redemptive work.

eschatology.urgency: Fatima's message contains a sense of eschatological urgency - the fate of souls and nations depends on response to heaven's call for conversion.
eschatology.conditionalProphecy: The prophecies are conditional: catastrophes can be averted through prayer, penance, and consecration.
eschatology.triumphOfImaculateHeart: The promise that 'in the end, my Immaculate Heart will triumph' offers hope despite warnings of persecution and suffering.

spiritualPractices.firstSaturdays: Mary requested Communion of Reparation on five consecutive First Saturdays, with confession, rosary, and 15-minute meditation on rosary mysteries
spiritualPractices.angelPrayers: The Angel of Portugal taught the children prayers of adoration and reparation, particularly 'O Most Holy Trinity...' and 'My God, I believe, I adore, I hope and I love You...'
spiritualPractices.sacrificeForSinners: The children's example of offering small daily sacrifices for the conversion of sinners

feastDay.name: Our Lady of Fatima
feastDay.rank: Optional Memorial in the Roman Calendar (added 2002)

pilgrimageDays.autumn: October 12-13 (anniversary of Miracle of the Sun)
pilgrimageDays.practices: Candlelight processions, Rosary, Mass at the Chapel of Apparitions, stations of the cross

liturgicalConnections.worldApostolate: The World Apostolate of Fatima (Blue Army) promotes the message internationally

chapelOfApparitions.location: Built on the exact spot of the apparitions at Cova da Iria
chapelOfApparitions.feature: Statue of Our Lady of Fatima marking the apparition site; outdoor altar

basilicaOfOurLadyOfTheRosary.features: Tombs of Lucia, Francisco, and Jacinta; 15 side altars depicting rosary mysteries

basilicaOfTheMostHolyTrinity.features: Largest Catholic church in Portugal; modern circular design

sacredSites.valinhos: Site where the Virgin appeared in August 1917 when the children were imprisoned by the civil administrator

ecclesiasticalApproval.localApproval: Bishop of Leiria declared the apparitions 'worthy of belief' (October 13, 1930)
papalRecognition: Pope Pius XII: Crowned the statue of Our Lady of Fatima (1946); consecrated the world to the Immaculate Heart (1942, 1952)
Pope Paul VI: Visited Fatima on 50th anniversary (1967); issued apostolic exhortation Signum Magnum

Pope John Paul II: Attributed his survival of the 1981 assassination to Our Lady of Fatima; placed the bullet in the crown of her statue; consecrated the world (1984); beatified Francisco and Jacinta (2000)
Pope Benedict XVI: Visited on 10th anniversary of beatification (2010)
Pope Francis: Canonized Francisco and Jacinta on 100th anniversary (May 13, 2017)
ecclesiasticalApproval.theologicalStatus: Private revelation - binding in faith on those to whom given, proposed to the faithful as worthy of belief but not part of the deposit of faith

comparativeNotes.otherApparitions: Fatima stands in a tradition of approved Marian apparitions including Guadalupe (1531), Rue du Bac (1830), La Salette (1846), Lourdes (1858), and more recently Kibeho (1981-1989, approved 2001). Each has distinctive characteristics while sharing common Marian themes.
comparativeNotes.distinctiveElements: Fatima is unique for: the Miracle of the Sun witnessed by tens of thousands; the detailed geopolitical prophecies; the sealed Third Secret; the connection to the 1981 papal assassination attempt; the canonization of the child visionaries as non-martyrs.
